column2: The Imperial Geographical Society is a body dedicated to the research and preservation of the geographical and historical knowledge of Tamriel. As a member of the organisation I may author and submit essays for review. If they are accepted, it would be a great boon to my prestige and standing within the Society, but if the quality is found to be lacking, it could do the reverse and harm my standing and prestige.

Author an essay on a geographical or historical subject for review by other members of the Society. If accepted, the essay will be entered into the Society's Library and your scholarly renown will increase.

Perform a geographical survey of <target_holding>, compiling various pieces of information such as the relief, waterways, roadways and a brief catalogue of the local fauna and flora.\nIf you are not the owner of the holding, you will have to gain permission of the owner before your survey may take place. The owner may even pay you for your services.\nDuring a survey you may come across artifacts or other hidden treasures such as ore deposits or previously unknown or forgotten ruins.  Be careful when opening them though, for the dead of Nirn are restless beasts.
The Imperial Geographical Society, while so-named, is an independent organisation funded by its members and patrons. As a member, you may make a voluntary financial contribution.

Donate an artifact to the Imperial Geographical Society's collection, housed in the Society's museum on the Imperial Isle, of which you are a member. Donating an artifact will increase your renown within the Society.

As a fellow of the Imperial Geographical Society, you may submit a book for consideration by other fellows and laureates. If the book is accepted, it will be published by the Society and made available across Tamriel. Your scholarly renown will increase drastically, and if the book is sufficiently acclaimed, you may even be awarded a laureate of your own!

Laureates and higher members of the Imperial Geographical Society occasionally host small informal feasts, followed by debates on various geographical, historical or even scientific" theories and ideas. If a debate goes well, you may well make new friends or rivals from within the Society, as well as increase your own standing by voicing your ideas and opinions. When you choose to host a dinner debate, invitations will be dispatched to all members of the Society. You will have several days to prepare for the feast after dispatching invitations."

A professional association of soldiers and sellswords, the Fighters Guild arose during the Second Era as Potentate Versidue-Shaie's replacement for standing armies. Though this purpose was short-lived, the Fighters Guild has since become the premier destination for law-abiding adventurers to learn the ways of the warrior and earn a living vanquishing outlaws, monsters, Daedra, and other dangers to the people of Tamriel.
The Master of the Fighters Guild.

The Iron Hilts are a fraternity of warriors spanning the diverse reaches of Akavir, but holding three things in common - a willingness to put aside differences, a desire for material wealth, and the martial skill to make a living by fighting. All of their weaponry uses hilts and grips gilded in dull, grey iron - a symbol of their loyalty to no particular side in Akavir's constant wars.
The Blademaster of the Iron Hilts.

A loose association of warriors and raiders, the Bear's Craft was born in the turmoil that gripped Atmora after Skyrim cut her ties. Bound not by honour like the famous Companions, but by the Glory of Battle, this group spends as much time fighting amongst themselves as they do fighting the Draugr that walk their lands.
The leader amongst the Halls of the Bear, bloodied and scarred yet ever victorious.

Since the ancient disaster that nearly destroyed the entire continent, the region comprising Yokuda is fractious and often quite dangerous. Hardy adventurers, eager to prove their mettle and make a fortune, venture across the islands, fighting outlaws and monsters wherever they can find them.
The Yokeda of the Guardsmen's Guild.

The Companions, Skyrim's ancient fighting force, traces its origins to the Five Hundred Companions who accompanied Ysgramor in his return from Atmora and subsequent war with the Snow Elves. Modern Companions strive to embody the heroic virtues of their Merethic-era predecessors and are renowned for a maintaining a strict code of honor, as well as for their superior skill-at-arms.

Founded by Vanus Galerion in the early Second Era, the Mages Guild is dedicated to providing the people of Tamriel with a scholarly and ethical environment in which to learn and practice magic, as well as goods and services pertaining to the arcane. The Mages Guild's extensive marketing of affordable potions, scrolls, staves, spellbooks and magical training across the continent has made the organization extraordinarily wealthy and, in turn, greatly influential.
The Arch-Mage of the Mages Guild.

The ancient organization known as the Transcendent Architects has existed for thousands of years, practicing the arcane arts and studying magickal phenomena in towers that dot Akavir's remotest peaks. Politics means little to them, as they typically perform their experiments far from civilization. However, they are willing to provide their services to anyone with the finances to support their enigmatic existence...or the determination to work with them.
The Most Transcendent of the Transcendent Architects.

A loosely-aligned consortium of Tamriel's leading businesspeople, Tamriel's Mercantile Guild provides and maintains commercial regulatory standards and contractual agreements. Ever-eager to strengthen their grasp on Tamriel's growing economy, the Mercantile Guild welcomes potential representatives with open arms, who can in turn draw upon its leaders' resources and experience to improve their own business acumen.
The Grandmaster of the Mercantile Guild.

Maritime trade thrives in Akavir because of the Eastern Continent's abundance of bays, lagoons, and natural harbors. The need for competent navigation gave rise to the Navigators of Akavir, who have gradually evolved from a small band of tradesmen into a fully-fledged trade guild spanning all of Akavir. Many shipping arrangements are done via the Navigators, and they offer a litany of other mercantile services as well.
The Admiral of the Navigators of Akavir.

Yokuda,a maritime continent, bustles with commerce. The rise of lawlessness that coincided with the sinking of the land required a strong reaction to bring matters into balance - an effort spearheaded by this commercial alliance of merchants, bankers and civil leaders. Not only does the Azurian Company enforce contracts and protect shipping, it also offers to teach mercantile skills to those who help uphold the company's interests.
The Grandmaster of the Mercantile Guild.

Aspiring painters, sculptors, poets, musicians, scribes and others all across Tamriel flock to the halls of the Scenarist Guild to learn the many facets of the veritable jewel that is the fine arts. Some full-fledged Scenarists find employment as the entertainers of wealthy patrons, while others serve as public historians who use their expertise to ensure the veracity of written records.
The Grandmaster of the Scenarist Guild.

The Ephemeral Wardens maintain that the truest beauty of one thing can exist only in one instance, never to be repeated. But they wish to one day defeat their self-imposed reality, and their artists - practitioners of music, dance, theater, sculpting and other media - tirelessly hone their skills to this end. Their services and products fetch exorbitant fees, and it is considered an honor to have an Ephemeral Warden perform at court.
The Pure-Brilliance of the Ephemeral Wardens.

Yokuda's Academy of Historians has two primary goals - first, to preserve the glory days of the continent in the historical record, and second, to instruct others on how to do the same. To this end, the guild provides a bevy of educational opportunities that can help artists improve their professional capabilities.
The Grandmaster of the Scenarist Guild.

There are many who believe that this shadowy institution is mythical, existing only in fiction and the rantings of town guards. In actuality, the Thieves Guild is quite real, though how exactly it functions is a matter known only to those in its inner circles. The greatest criminals in all of Tamriel constantly plot - and execute - their audacious heists, hoping that Lady Luck may be on their side. Those crafty enough to find the Thieves Guild and careful enough to adhere to its many rules can share in its legendary riches.
The Master Thief of the Thieves Guild.

In Morrowind, the presence of the Thieves Guild has long been stymied by the dominance of the Camonna Tong, an old criminal syndicate. Comprised entirely of Dunmer, members of the Camonna Tong are fiercely opposed to the influence of any foreigners on Morrowind's culture. Their various enterprises, such as smuggling, slaving and murder-for-hire, are all steeped in xenophobic goals.
The Kingpin of the Camonna Tong.
The Master Thief of the Silent Moons.

One of the supreme guilds of assassins found in Tamriel, the Dark Brotherhood is notorious for its secretive recruiting methods, its devotion to Sithis - the very personification of chaos - and its terrifying efficiency at eliminating any target, no matter how tough or crafty. Most of Tamriel's leaders outwardly despise and have outlawed the Dark Brotherhood, yet many of these people are the ones who so often call upon the Night Mother to dispose of their foes.
The Listener of the Dark Brotherhood.

Active since the First Era, the Morag Tong is perhaps Tamriel's most ancient association of assassins. Headquartered in Morrowind and devoted to the Daedric Prince Mephala, the Morag Tong is supported within its homeland as a legitimate means to dispose of any and all enemies and settle disputes quickly and efficiently. This does not mean that every contract killing is legal, however, and each assassination order requires a verifiable writ to guarantee its lawfulness.
The Grandmaster of the Morag Tong.

A mysterious group of assassins, they assimilated or eliminated all the other groups by pandering to some of the most unusual tastes their clients could have. While most groups of murderers would be satisfied with a mindless slaughter, the Order of the Pale Mist prides itself in creating "art" from their acts of killing.
The Mist Walker of the Order of the Pale Mist.

The Greybeards were founded by Jurgen Windcaller in the early First Era, in response to the Thuum-wielding Nord army's disastrous defeat at Red Mountain. Jurgen established the Way of the Voice, which uses the Thuum only for the worship of the gods and strives to keep spirit and actions in harmony. Those who devote themselves to the Way of the Voice can harness their inner strength and project a mighty Shout.
The most respected of the Greybeards.

An extremely old monastic society which originally built its reputation producing genealogical silken shawls, the modern Moth Priests are most famous for their superior ability to read the Elder Scrolls. Diving knowledge from these fragments of time is an exceptionally difficult process, and it can take years of rigorous training before a member of the order is properly prepared to read their first Scroll.
The Exarch of the Moth Priests.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Dres values Dunmer traditionalism, in particular obedience to the Temple, emphasis on agriculture and commerce, and the preservation of slavery.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Hlaalu upholds the Hlaalu virtues of cosmopolitanism and friendliness to outsiders, along with the use of cunning and subversion to eliminate enemies.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Indoril is well-known for its absolute loyalty toward the Tribunal Temple, and the leaders of House Indoril are deeply intertwined with Temple hierarchy and policies.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Redoran stresses the virtues of duty, gravity and piety. They support the Temple and are dedicated to protecting the Dunmer people from internal and external threats.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Telvanni is notorious for its amorality, isolationism and opportunism. Although they tend to despise outsiders, they greatly reward any who have the aptitude to fulfill their personal ambitions.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Sadras, much like the old House Hlaalu, is pragmatic and open-minded, though they strongly prefer Dunmer people and customs over those of Outlanders.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. Fiercely traditionalist, House Sul embraces the ancient ways of the tribal Ashlanders, particularly a warrior culture and the belief that the Nerevarine, the reincarnation of Nerevar, has been sent to destroy the Tribunal and the Sixth House alike.

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Veloth seeks to preserve the ancient ways of life that were developed by the prophet Veloth and the Chimer who first followed him into the land of Resdayn. This includes High Velothi culture, as well as worship of ancestors and the three Good Daedra" - Azura, Boethiah and Mephala."

In Velothi politics, each Great House has a council - a ruling body of elite individuals - who dictate policy, choose leaders, and administer their House territories. The Council of House Dagoth is fanatically devoted to the worship of Dagoth Ur, its immortal Lord High Councilor, as the god and savior of the Dunmer people who will destroy the Tribunal, exterminate Outlander influences, and transform the world with the power of the Blight.
